What it doesn't talk about is the greater impending crisis of debt. How the bad paper debt,the national debt and private debt are going to play out is the great unknown. But 'lenders' don't like bathing - as is demonstrated in the Chrysler bankruptcy, and they'll be lining up for help before the ordinary joes. They would be even more unhappy with anything less than a full-value buck.

content: Waddya mean? What's with all this gloom and doom stuff? Things are looking up! The Stock Market has ONLY lost 40% of its value. Home prices have ONLY dropped about 20%. (50% if you live in California or Florida) The Economy has ONLY lost 5.5 MILLION jobs. (Make it an even 6 MILLION after Friday's US Employment Report) And here's the best news of all: Ben Bernanke, the man who told Americans last year that the economy was strong and that there would be NO recession....... is now telling us that...... things are NOT as bad as some people are making them out to be. Thanks, Uncle Ben! Yip, Yip, Yipeeeeeeeeee!!! Get out there and SPEND, SPEND, SPEND!!!

content: Well, things are certainly rosier than ever! The economy lost ONLY 539,000 jobs in April 2009! (Not even CLOSE to 1,000,000!) The unemployment rate is now ONLY 8.9%! (It ONLY went up by .4%!) Since the recession began in December 2007, the economy has ONLY lost 5.7 MILLION jobs, NOT 6 MILLION as I said earlier! (There are about 13.7 MILLION unemployed workers in America but, who's counting!) Banks need ONLY $75 BILLION more in taxpayer bailout funds! (A far cry from the $750 BILLION we gave em just a few months ago!) The National Debt is NOT $15,000,000,000,000! It's ONLY $11,233,221,767,468! Waddya waitin' fer? Buy some shares in the stock market (they're a bargain)! Take out a second (third ? fourth ?) mortgage! C'mon people, let's show the world that the American consumer may be down, but he's not out!

title: The Economy: History Repeats?

content: Missing in the analysis is the fact that the 'Great Depression' was actually three great crisis, not just a series of crashes in the New York Stock Market. 1. The first was the NY stock market crash of '29 followed by a series of smaller crashes and the general slide in the market until 1932. 2. The period of unusually wet summers in the great plains ended in 1930, beginning four straight years of drought that resulted in the loss of over 100,000,000 acres of farmland (an area twice the size of the entire state of Nebraska). Known as 'the dustbowl', the area had already been financially hit by falling prices for agricultural goods in the decade after WWI. 2% of the entire US population suddenly became homeless migrants and the value of US farmland plummeted to the lowest level in half a century. 3. The Smoot-Hawley Tarriff Act of 1930 and the subsequent response of all our trading partners caused a 66% drop in exports and a 61% drop in imports, basically halting foreign trade at the precise moment it was needed to lessen the impact of the Stock Market Crash. The original intent was to protect US production by increasing the price of foreign goods. The real impact was an almost universal rejection of US goods and a deepening of the depression. In our current crisis, only one of those three events has occured. US farmland is now trading at twice the value that it was just ten years ago (Reference: +http://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSN2549405520090225+) and our import/export levels are the highest in our history (Ref: +http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/Press-Release/2008pr/04/ft900.pdf+). Is the current crisis bad? Yes it is. Does it match the conditions that resulted in the Great Depression? Not even close. We would need several more financial crashes equal to what we've already seen to match the 1930s. Quit panicking. Sullivan013
reply: Missing in the analysis is the fact that the 'Great Depression' was actually three great crisis, not just a series of crashes in the New York Stock Market. 1. The original intent was to protect US production by increasing the price of foreign goods. The real impact was an almost universal rejection of US goods and a deepening of the depression. In our current crisis, only one of those three events has occured. US farmland is now trading at twice the value that it was just ten years ago (Reference: +http://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSN2549405520090225+) and our import/export levels are the highest in our history (Ref: +http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/Press-Release/2008pr/04/ft900.pdf+). Is the current crisis bad? Yes it is. Does it match the conditions that resulted in the Great Depression? Not even close. We would need several more financial crashes equal to what we've already seen to match the 1930s. Quit panicking. Sullivan013

content: quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: Quit panicking. That's what we were being told before the stock market lost 40%. That's what Californians were being told before their homes lost HALF of their value. That's what the WorldCom and Enron CEOs were telling their employees and stockholders before their companies collapsed. I'm sure that's what Mr. Madoff was telling his clients while he was preparing to flee the country. You're right, of course, Don't panic. Panic is irrational and leads to bad decisions. But it is even more dangerous (and expensive) to be complacent. Anyone who is buying into the "light at the end of the tunnel" speeches by Bernanke and Geithner deserve to lose their money and assets. They are just plain DUMB. America will be digging herself out of this fiscal MESS for YEARS to come.

content: Ah, daybreak is just a few hours away and another Monday beckons. Another week of watching the wild, wacky, wonderful roller coaster known as the "Stock Market". Will it go up? title: The Economy: History Repeats?

content: Smoot-Hawley = good? Not in the real world. It was an unmitigated disaster for both the US consumer and the US worker. Don't kid yourself about the whole 'protecting US jobs' rant. In the end, protectionist legislation like Smoot-Hawley increased unemployment more than it saved US jobs. Like any price change for goods and services, the foreign consumer went elsewhere, dropping US goods and causing inventory storage problems as domestic consumption could not keep up with supply. As prices fell in response, profit margins evaporated and wages fell accordingly. In the end, more factories went bust than were saved by Smoot-Hawley. Current protectionism, if allowed to become law, will have similiar results. There has NEVER been a society that has benefitted from trade restrictions on foreign goods in the long run. Sullivan013
reply: Smoot-Hawley = good? Not in the real world. It was an unmitigated disaster for both the US consumer and the US worker. Don't kid yourself about the whole 'protecting US jobs' rant. Like any price change for goods and services, the foreign consumer went elsewhere, dropping US goods and causing inventory storage problems as domestic consumption could not keep up with supply. As prices fell in response, profit margins evaporated and wages fell accordingly. In the end, more factories went bust than were saved by Smoot-Hawley. Current protectionism, if allowed to become law, will have similiar results. There has NEVER been a society that has benefitted from trade restrictions on foreign goods in the long run. Sullivan013

Sullivan013 Smoot/Hawley, in the short run, hurt, in the long run, it helped, I acknowledged that fully... It also caused "spot" shortages and price increases but, as business' returned, market forces forced the prices back down and enabled the United States to have the basic industries on shore to fight the second world war... Think long term and not in the moment... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Smoot/Hawley, in the short run, hurt, in the long run, it helped Not by any measurable statistic on record. I don't know where you're getting your information, but I'll bet it isn't from any reputable source. My source: +http://future.state.gov/when/timeline/1921_timeline/smoot_tariff.html+ quote: It forced the industries back on shore, so that when the recovery, in the long run, took place, the jobs and facilities were there... The "recovery" you speak of was the war effort, in which existing factories played a part, but predominantly NEW factories were built over old for the newer production lines. In short, the 'jobs' lost during the 30s never rematerialized, they simply opened in war industries with the government as the sole buyer (which sent our national debt through the roof). As soon as the war ended, the Breton Woods agreement finally ended Smoot-Hawley and we began to trade again. Our national debt took thirty years to drop down to what it was in 1940. quote: It also caused "spot" shortages and price increases but, as business' returned, market forces forced the prices back down and enabled the United States to have the basic industries on shore to fight the second world war... What are you talking about? What part of 'failed industries' are you missing? Losing 60% of your external market for goods and services is not a "spot shortage", it kills your business. Failed businesses add to unemployment, lost external orders, failed shipyards (who needs ships when fewer goods are being transported?), losses in rail contracts, and the domestic market during a recession/depression isn't going to make up any part of your profits. An unemployed welder is not an "untapped resource that'll be ready when we need it", it's a hungry guy who can no longer feed his family. My parents lived through the depression, and their stories were about as bleak as any other. My mother didn't enlist until 1944, and she had no more to eat in '43 than she did in '34. At best she would admit that during the war, things were 'a little better'(but not by much). You can't sugarcoat Smoot-Hawley. It hurt us. I hurt our economy and it increased suffering of our people for over a decade. Next you'll be saying that slavery helped the slaves "in the long run...." Sullivan013
quote: Smoot/Hawley, in the short run, hurt, in the long run, it helped
reply: Not by any measurable statistic on record. I don't know where you're getting your information, but I'll bet it isn't from any reputable source. My source: +http://future.state.gov/when/timeline/1921_timeline/smoot_tariff.html+ quote: It forced the industries back on shore, so that when the recovery, in the long run, took place, the jobs and facilities were there... The "recovery" you speak of was the war effort, in which existing factories played a part, but predominantly NEW factories were built over old for the newer production lines. Our national debt took thirty years to drop down to what it was in 1940. quote: It also caused "spot" shortages and price increases but, as business' returned, market forces forced the prices back down and enabled the United States to have the basic industries on shore to fight the second world war... What are you talking about? What part of 'failed industries' are you missing? Losing 60% of your external market for goods and services is not a "spot shortage", it kills your business. Failed businesses add to unemployment, lost external orders, failed shipyards (who needs ships when fewer goods are being transported?), losses in rail contracts, and the domestic market during a recession/depression isn't going to make up any part of your profits. An unemployed welder is not an "untapped resource that'll be ready when we need it", it's a hungry guy who can no longer feed his family. My parents lived through the depression, and their stories were about as bleak as any other. My mother didn't enlist until 1944, and she had no more to eat in '43 than she did in '34. At best she would admit that during the war, things were 'a little better'(but not by much). You can't sugarcoat Smoot-Hawley. It hurt us. I hurt our economy and it increased suffering of our people for over a decade. Next you'll be saying that slavery helped the slaves "in the long run...." Sullivan013
title: The Economy: History Repeats?
